user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GetResourceName:
```c
int32 OS_GetResourceName(osal_id_t object_id, char *buffer, size_t buffer_size)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    size_t              name_len;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* sanity check the passed-in buffer and size */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(buffer);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(buffer_size);

    /*
     * Initially set the output string to empty.
     * This avoids undefined behavior in case the function fails
     * and the caller does not check the return code.
     */
    buffer[0] = 0;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(object_id), object_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken(&token);

        if (record->name_entry != NULL)
        {
            name_len = OS_strnlen(record->name_entry, buffer_size);
            if (buffer_size <= name_len)
            {
                /* indicates the name does not fit into supplied buffer */
                return_code = OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG;
                name_len    = buffer_size - 1;
            }
            memcpy(buffer, record->name_entry, name_len);
            buffer[name_len] = 0;
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GetResourceName:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
static inline osal_objtype_t OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(osal_id_t id)
{
    return (OS_ObjectIdToInteger(id) >> OS_OBJECT_TYPE_SHIFT);
}
...
OS_common_record_t *OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    uint32 base_idx = OS_GetBaseForObjectType(token->obj_type);
    return &OS_common_table[base_idx + token->obj_idx];
}
...
uint32 OS_GetBaseForObjectType(osal_objtype_t idtype)
{
    switch (idtype)
    {
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK:
            return OS_TASK_BASE;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_QUEUE:
            return OS_QUEUE_BASE;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_BINSEM:
            return OS_BINSEM_BASE;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_COUNTSEM:
            return OS_COUNTSEM_BASE;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MUTEX:
            return OS_MUTEX_BASE;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM:
            return OS_STREAM_BASE;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_DIR:
            return OS_DIR_BASE;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE:
            return OS_TIMEBASE_BASE;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB:
            return OS_TIMECB_BASE;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MODULE:
            return OS_MODULE_BASE;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_FILESYS:
            return OS_FILESYS_BASE;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONSOLE:
            return OS_CONSOLE_BASE;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR:
            return OS_CONDVAR_BASE;
        default:
            return 0;
    }
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG (-13)
...
static inline size_t OS_strnlen(const char *s, size_t maxlen)
{
    const char *end = (const char *)memchr(s, 0, maxlen);
    if (end != NULL)
    {
        /* actual length of string is difference */
        maxlen = end - s;
    }
    return maxlen;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 concerns the well-formedness of for statements. I inspected all provided code fragments (OS_GetResourceName, OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl, OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken, OS_GetBaseForObjectType, OS_ObjectIdRelease, OS_strnlen, and the shown macros/constants). None of these fragments contain any for statements. The macros shown (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_CHECK_SIZE) do not expand to for loops in the provided definitions. The switch, if, and function-call constructs present are not subject to Rule 14.2. Therefore there are no for-loop code fragments in the supplied code that need investigation under Rule 14.2. Note: if there are other source files or macro definitions not provided here (or library implementations of called routines) that contain for statements, those would need to be inspected; however, based solely on the supplied code, there are no for loops to report.
